pullRequest.body:
Add command `lake exe autolabel 17062` which uses `git diff` to find changes compared to `master`, searches for applicable GitHub topic labels (based on a defined mapping), and adds them to the PR using `gh`.

Add GitHub workflow calling the script on creation of a new PR, automatically adding topic labels to the PR if applicable.

---

- [x] Counterproposal to #15938 (only one of the two should be merged!)




Currently two potential issues come to mind:

- anybody calling `lake exe autolabel 10000` locally on their machine might add random labels to an arbitrary PR. This will say their name (and not a bot). I guess this is fine since it is by choice that any contributor can arbitrarily modify github labels...

See PR in action here: #17088 and #17083 (no label as two were found, see [CI run](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11013546073/job/30582139194#step:4:46))

<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [8fdf59c55c](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/17062/commits/8fdf59c55c0f680caffd3088c160c82b725b69ef)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Label`
`+ _root_.System.FilePath.isPrefixOf`
`+ getMatchingLabels`
`+ githubAnnotation`
`+ mathlibLabels`
`+ mathlibUnlabelled`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

@adomani what's your opinion? Would you have the time to check that the logic is equivalent to yours? (I think it should be...)

@semorrison since you've reviewed the other PR, do you like this version better?

My personal opinion on which of these is preferrable:
- the other PR makes it much more convenient to add new labels, to the point of hiding all core logic behind an environment extension - but that means 100-200 lines for environment extensions, make that implementation more complicated and harder to understand. (I certainly don't understand that part, at the moment.)
- this PR just does the "minimal" thing, in a nice way. Adding a new label requires editing the list of labels in the implementation, but that seems reasonable enough (and the implementation is not too hard to read). So, I think it's good enough in practice.

Two more questions about this PR:
- should the executable error if not automatic label was found (e.g., when a directory `Geometry/Hyperbolic` is added, which is not covered by any rule)? (You'd have to exclude `scripts` from that error, but otherwise it looks like it could work.)
- ~~if a PR is labelled wrongly, can this be corrected manually? Or does the workflow run on every *push* (as opposed to once, when the PR is filed)~~ resolved now

In any case: thanks a lot, both of you, for working on this - this piece of automation will be great to have!
Did you mean to remove the exit code 3 again?
(Otherwise, if CI passes etc, feel free to maintainer merge on my behalf - perhaps after asking Damiano's opinion as well.)

As it seems Michael and Damiano are happy with this, in addition to my comment about `gh` above, please also fill out the commit message a little bit more (at least `lake exe autolabel` should be mentioned), and then we can test this out in production:
bors d+

:v: joneugster can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

Here are 4 test-PRs showing the expected outcomes:

- [warning if topic labels do not cover everything](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/17166/files#diff-914f28d3d564a9e54089bda43485720d093959a94c038587b1edff9d0713268d)
- [error if included path does not exist](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/17163/files#diff-914f28d3d564a9e54089bda43485720d093959a94c038587b1edff9d0713268d)
- [error if excluded path does not exist](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/17167/files#diff-914f28d3d564a9e54089bda43485720d093959a94c038587b1edff9d0713268d)
- [successfully added "CI" label](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/17168)

@jcommelin you wanted to look over this again and merge.

Since delegation, I modified the warning/error message (i.e. added `githubAnnotation`) and added `"Mathlib" / "Std"` as exception, since this seemed to have appeared in the last day or so.

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11056637748/job/30718631097)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11056637748/job/30718631426)

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

Thanks a lot for implementing an alternative!

I like the executable!

I find adding more labels a little less streamlined than in the other PR, but I also don't think that adding new labels is something that will happen a lot!

Would you mind adding some tests for the `getMatchingLabels` function?

Thanks for writing this alternative. Because it avoids environment extensions, I can review it in depth - the implementation looks good to me. (I have one question about correctness, and otherwise just documentation/style comments.)
A few typos, and one last comment. After that, I'd maintainer merge (though perhaps @adomani) should rather do so).

I'm really happy with this version!

I also had autoparameters in one of the iterations of the EnvExtension PR.  I think that they worked less well there, but they look very good here!

Thanks!

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

```suggestion
def mathlibLabels : Array Label := #[
```
Here is my reasoning for the changes:
* a file in `scripts` will not be imported, so `private` seems superfluous;
* `mathlibLabels` is used only once and immediately converted to an `Array`, so it might as well be an `Array`!
Would you mind adding a doc-string to this definition?  It shows that I've been playing with linters for a while, doesn't it?  :smile:

```suggestion
      "Mathlib" / "LinearAlgebra" ] },
```
just for consistency with the space at the opening of the bracket.
I don't have a strong opinion on this, so I replaced the Array with the result of pretty-printing it (modulo some line breaks)

```suggestion
      println s!"No PR-number provided, skipping adding labels. \
```
maybe?

After working on the review dashboard for long enough, I became very aware of this difference. What do you think of clarifying?
```suggestion
* The `label` field is the actual GitHub label name.
not a native speaker, but I wonder: would "labelled with" `label` read better?
Perhaps add a sentence like this one? "Any modifications to a file in an excluded path is ignored for the purposes of labelling."
Similar to the above

The following is needed, right?
```suggestion
      "Mathlib" / "Geometry" / "RingedSpace" ] },
Speaking of which: can you add a check to the executable about path components containing a full stop? That seems likely enough that it's worth catching :-)
Dumb question ( also @adomani ), how do I test a script? I don't think I can add `test/autolabel.lean` and `import scripts.autolabel`, can I?

I had in mind something like
```lean
run_cmd
  if getMatchingLabels input != desiredOutput then
    logWarning "Test failed"
```
Not too highbrow, but at least it shows what some representative inputs get converted to.
ok, I've did the same with `#guard` which is about equivalent
Here and below: please add a space before the closing `}`. Up to you if you prefer to write `dirs` on one line.

That directory does not exist.
```suggestion

My favourite style nit: please use \mapsto instead of => for anonymous functions.
(If you prefer, I can push one commit fixing all these minor style things directly.)

Perhaps I'm paranoid, but: does this do the right thing with `Algebra` vs `AlgebraicGeometry` directories? (I would expect that some prefix logic based on file paths would be more robust; perhaps this already suffices. If this works, perhaps a comment is useful.)
In any case, can you add a test for this?
Good spot, the old version had a workaround I didn't copy!
Can you print an error if there is not exactly one argument?
Do you mean as `println` as pushed now? or is there a better way?
The current way looks good to me.
@grunweg re hiding implementation from the user, this could be a separate JSON file instead of a `def` if you'd prefer that?
We could also use an `IO.Ref` and recycle some of the syntax from the other PR, but avoiding Environment extensions.  After all, everything happens in one file only.
nvm, that would be less nice with the filepaths...
I think the current logic is good enough.
@grunweg I updated the workflow, so now it only triggers once when the PR is opened (and there is an option to dispatch it manually from the github UI)

There is one catch with this:

Since the workflow only triggers once, one could add a new folder in say the second commit to the PR. This might lead to a passing CI but a new PR created will then complain that not all of Mathlib is covered by the labels....

Do we need a test that all of mathlib is covered by labels? If so, could we run it say just once a week or so and just post a Zulip message or something like that? I'd really like to avoid forcing people to have to solve unrelated CI issues in their PRs if something sneaks through in someone else's PR...
I ended up that this only triggers a warning. So there might be an unexpected warning on future PRs, but at least it should not cause anything to fail.

```suggestion
the mathlib repository. The script uses `git diff` to determine which files

```suggestion
  Any modifications to a file in an excluded path are ignored for the purposes of labelling. -/

```suggestion
Mathlib labels and their corresponding folders. Add new labels and folders here!

How about this?
```suggestion
Return all names of labels in `mathlibLabels` which match

```suggestion
  -- validate that all paths in `mathlibLabels` actually exist
I like the validation check you added. I meant to (also) throw an error if this branch is reached --- unless the PR modifies e.g. only `scripts`.

I'm a bit hesitant to make this failing for the following reasons:

- it will mean the PR gets a red cross because there was no applicable label, even if the PR is passing CI otherwise. (I'm pretty sure there is no way to make CI pass despite a single workflow failing).
- There are still plenty of folders/files which are not covered by any label. For example most things in `Counterexamples`, `Archive`, in the root dir, `Mathlib/[Testing,Deprecated,Init]`. It seems unreasonable to me that the CI should fail on any PR modifying these labels.

However, I did add a test ensuring that all subfolders of `Mathlib/` are covered by a label, which might address your concerns in a way?
Good points - makes sense to not make CI fail. The current test is good enough for me!

```suggestion
      "Mathlib" / "LinearAlgebra"] },
```
How about adding a `pathExists` check for all the dirs?

Sorry for the confusion, I was playing around, forgot to add the "WIP" label and went offline...

There is a check in place that all paths exist and the workflow fails otherwise!

```suggestion
  There is `AutoLabel.mathlibUnlabelled` to add exceptions for this test.
```
Will this work even if the workflow is triggered with `workflow_dispatch`?

I think I cannot test it since the dispatch button does not appear... or at least I do not get a dispatch button?

Maybe the dispatch button only appears for workflows on `master`?
Looking at google, I think it will not work... Maybe I remove the `workflow_dispatch` then...
Yeah, workflow_dispatch only works when it's in `master`

It would be good to mention that `gh` is requried to be installed for this to be work since even people contributing to mathlib might not have it / be aware of it (it's not mentioned in our info for contributors, right?)

Maybe it should also be mentioned in the module doc / docstrings in the lean file as well? (and in an error message if gh is missing?)
Doing both sounds good to me. (I haven't checked if `gh` needs to be configured some way, perhaps that can be added as well.)

Done.

* I did not add an extra error message if `gh` is not installed, but the user will get something like ``unknown command: `gh`.`` (or whatever `bash` says). And I added the note about requiring `gh` to every docstring the user could possibly look at.
* Installing `gh` is just following the official installation instructions (e.g. https://github.com/cli/cli?tab=readme-ov-file#installation) which are basically installing the os-dependent binaries and running `gh auth login` to authenticate, but no special setup.

```suggestion
    dirs := #[".github"] },
```
the "main build" file is now in `.github` (although modifying it implies also modifying files inside `workflows`).

We catch a couple of other files in `.github` but not in `.github/workflows` as well.

```suggestion
    println s!"autolabel: invalid number of arguments ({args.length}), expected at most 1. \
    Please run without arguments or provide the target PR's number as single argument!"
```

```suggestion
        println s!"::error file=scripts/autolabel.lean,line=60::directory {dir} does not exist! \
```
what does `line=60` refer to?

`line=84` (updated) is supposed to be roughly the definition of `def mathlibLabels : Array Label`.

I don't know a way to find this automatically. Should I just do `line=1` instead?

This may work (untested):
```lean
 line := ((declRangeExt.find? ( getEnv) `Autolabel.mathlibLabels).getD default).range.pos.line
```
hmm, but I'm in `IO` and don't really have access to the `env`. Usually I would use `withImportModules` in this case, but that does not work since `script/autolabel.lean` is not importable.
How about saying "directory `foo` in `mathlibLabels` does not exist"? This avoids line numbers at all, but is hopefully equally informative.
Maybe it is simply easier to skip the line number, mention the file and the declaration name and be happy with it!
done

```suggestion
    -- note: only emitting a warning because the workflow is only triggered on the first commit
```

```suggestion
    Please run without arguments or provide the target PR's number as a single argument!"
```
Should this error give a bit more detailed instructions to the unlucky user whose PR has a red cross mark?

Updated it to


> Misformatted `AutoLabel.mathlibLabels`
> 
> scripts/autolabel.lean: directory 'Mathlib/LinearAlgebras' does not exist but is included by label 't-algebra'. Please update `AutoLabel.mathlibLabels`!

(see examples)

Also I realised that I can add the following to the workflow:

```
on:
  push:
    paths:
      - scripts/autolabel.lean
      - .github/workflows/add_label_from_diff.yaml
```

Now the workflow will re-trigger whenever you modify the `autolabel` script, immediately throwing the error.

I think now the only way to trigger an error on a future PR is to merge a PR which deletes an entire subfolder of `Mathlib` but didn't do so in any commit present when the PR was created.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: add CI to auto-label PRs
